awd_titl_txt: RI:Small: Online Maximization Algorithms for Streaming Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Although existing machine learning (ML) methods are effective for analyzing data that are static in nature, many of today's applications from information retrieval to web searching require real-time processing of massive amounts of streaming data. Often, the data is available in an online fashion, meaning the entire dataset is not available at once, but rather, individual data instances arrive sequentially. Area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC) has been proven to be an effective evaluation metric and learning objective in many application domains, but it is difficult to optimize directly. To date, there are no satisfactory approaches to incorporate AUC into online ML algorithms for classification and ranking problems. This project will address the fundamental theoretical and algorithmic challenges in ML algorithms based on AUC maximization for processing streaming, high-dimensional data with efficient algorithms and theoretical analysis. The results of this project are expected to have broader impact in intrusion detection for cyber-security, fault detection in safety critical systems, information retrieval and cancer diagnosis. The planned research will also integrate with educational activities, including developing new undergraduate/graduate courses on optimization and machine learning, organizing a workshop and making software tools freely available to the public. The principal investigators also plan to undertake outreach activities to improve STEM learning of high school students.

A central topic of this project is to develop efficient online learning algorithms for AUC maximization and bipartite ranking, making them amenable for online processing of high dimensional and large volume of streaming data. This project also establishes a rigorous statistical foundation and thorough theoretical analysis of the online AUC maximization algorithms developed. The primary technical challenge in developing online AUC maximization algorithms and theory is that the objective functions involve statistically dependent pairs of instances while individual instances continuously arrive in a sequential order. This is in contrast to standard classification based on accuracy, where the loss functions only depend on individual instances and the related algorithms and theory are well developed. The project will address this gap by sufficiently exploiting the structures of the population objective involved in the problem of AUC maximization, rather than an empirical objective on finite data, through novel interaction of machine learning, statistical theory and applied mathematics. This will help to remove the pairwise structure in the original objective function and facilitate the development of efficient online learning algorithms for AUC maximization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In many machine learning tasks such as anomaly detection, imbalanced classification, and bipartite ranking, the area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a widely used performance measure instead of classification accuracy. As such, the learning problem based on AUC performance (referred to as AUC maximization) is of wide theoretical interest and significant practical importance. The aim of this project is to design efﬁcient online learning algorithms for AUC maximization and bipartite ranking for massive streaming data and develop a uniﬁed statistical foundation. 

Previous approaches directly adapt existing online learning algorithms to the setting of AUC maximization which needs to compare a new example to all previously measured ones. This leads to an expensive memory requirement to store previous data and needs to scan the training data multiple times, i.e., O(n) times when n samples are available. This renders existing algorithms infeasible for analyzing the massive streaming data in AUC maximization.  Our new approach is based on the reformulation of its population objective function, which is related to pairs of samples, as a stochastic saddle point (min-max) problem in which the new population objective only depends on a single random example. Our approach successfully removes the pairwise structure in the original objective function and facilitates the development of efﬁcient online learning algorithms for AUC maximization.

Based on this min-max formulation mentioned above, we have developed various fast optimization algorithms and extended them to different learning settings such as AUC maximization with neural network structures, general loss functions, federated learning, differential privacy, etc. The algorithms we developed can process each new sample with cheap per-iteration and storage complexities of one datum, and only need to pass the data once, making them amenable for massive streaming data analysis. Furthermore, we develop their statistical generalization analysis (as a special case of pairwise learning) using the concept of algorithmic stability which guarantees the output of such optimization algorithms can generalize well on future test data. 

The project resulted in 22 refereed conference and journal publications with most of them published in top-tier machine learning conferences.  The project has partly supported three Ph.D. students, Shu Hu from the CS department and Michael Natole and Zhenhuan Yang from the Math and Statistics department, and one postdoc, Dr. Feng Yu at the Math and Statistics Department. In particular, the project serves as a basis for Michael's and Zhenhuan's Ph.D. theses.  All these students received mentorship from both PIs, and the project provided them with opportunities for exposure to different research ideas and environments at both the CS and Math and Statistics departments.  Shu is now a postdoc at CMU, Michael is a process data scientist for Regeneron and Zhenhuan is a data scientist at Etsy. The postdoc, Dr. Feng Yu, who was supported for one year, continues his postdoc training at Old Dominion University. The PI has supervised a local high-school junior from Albany Academy to do a student research project which uses machine learning methods to automatically identify seizures in mice based on EEG data. The PIs have organized various workshops and mini-symposiums at data science and statistics conferences such as EcoSta and SIAM MDS.
